choices.text: 90 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
80 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
100 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds
70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds

questions.text: Which of the following fits into the criteria of severe variable deceleration, variations less than: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds.

 

Severe variable decelerations in fetal heart rate (FHR) are characterized by a significant reduction in the heart rate below the baseline. The specific criterion for a severe variable deceleration is when the heart rate drops below 70 beats per minute and this reduction persists for at least 60 seconds.

 

Variable decelerations are sudden decreases in the FHR that occur with or without contractions. They are commonly caused by umbilical cord compression, which impedes blood flow through the umbilical vein and arteries, leading to a reduction in fetal cardiac output. This type of deceleration is defined by a decrease of at least 15 beats per minute below the baseline and typically lasts between 15 seconds and less than 2 minutes.

 

Classification of Variable Decelerations:

 

  • Mild: Heart rate decreases to greater than 80 beats per minute regardless of duration, or decelerations lasting less than 30 seconds regardless of the heart rate, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting less than 60 seconds.
  • Moderate: Heart rate decreases to more than 70 beats per minute for 30-60 seconds, or heart rate between 70-80 beats per minute lasting more than 60 seconds.
  • Severe: Heart rate decreases to less than 70 beats per minute for an extended duration (at least 60 seconds).

 

(70 beats per minute lasting for 60 seconds) meets the criteria for severe variable deceleration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe variable decelerations are defined by a fetal heart rate dropping to less than 70 beats per minute for at least 60 seconds, typically due to umbilical cord compression.

choices.text: Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year
Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year
Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age
Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sign indicating adequate growth in an infant with a birth weight of 3 kg? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increase in length by 25 cm in the first year

 

Correct sign to indicate adequate growth in an infant is an increase in length of 25 cm in the first year.

 

Normal length of a newborn - 48-50cm (increase by 50% at 1st year = 75cm)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weight gain of 300 grams per month till 1 year: An infant gain weight at a rate of approximately 20-40 g per day for the first 3 months of life. Thereafter, they gain about 400 g weight every month for the remaining part of the first year.

 

Option C. Anterior fontanelle closure by 6 months of age:

 

 

Option D. Weight under 75th percentile and height under 25th percentile: According to WHO growth charts, weight and height under 50th percentile do not indicate adequate growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in length by 25 cm in the first year is a key indicator of adequate growth in infants.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best indicator of some dehydration in SAM? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output, Thirst & oral mucosa

 

Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) in children can present as either Kwashiorkor or Marasmus. These conditions cause the child to appear very thin and emaciated, making it challenging to rely on typical physical signs like skin pinch or sunken eyeballs for dehydration assessment. SAM children, especially those with Marasmus, already have a "baggy pant" appearance and very thin skin, making these signs unreliable.

 

The most reliable indicator of dehydration in SAM children is assessing urine output, thirst and the condition of the oral mucosa:

 

  • ⁠Urine output, thirst: If the child eagerly drinks water, it indicates some dehydration. Refusal to drink or feed may suggest severe dehydration.
  • ⁠Oral mucosa: Checking the dryness of the oral mucosa is a practical and reliable method. In SAM children, if the oral mucosa is dry, it indicates dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Skin pinch: This option is incorrect because SAM children already have very thin skin, making skin pinch an unreliable indicator.

 

Option B. Sunken eyeballs: This option is incorrect as SAM children naturally have sunken eyeballs due to severe weight loss and malnutrition, making this sign unreliable for detecting dehydration.

 

Option D. Absent tears: this indicator is not the best indicator. It can be seen in some as well as severe dehydration cases. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In SAM children, the best indicators of dehydration are urine output, the dryness of the oral mucosa and the child's thirst.

questions.text: Identify the disease shown in the karyotype: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cri-du-chat syndrome

 

  • Cri-du-chat syndrome: partial deletion of short arm of Chr 5, leads to cat-like cry, microcephaly, mental retardation, and congenital heart disease.
  • Bloom syndrome: rare autosomal recessive disorder, characterized by short stature, sun sensitivity, predeposition of development of cancer and genomic instability.
  • Angelman syndrome: caused by deletion in maternal chromosome 15 or paternal uniparental disomy, affects nervous system, delayed development, intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, and ataxia.
  • Fragile X syndrome: genetic disorder, also known as Martin-Bell syndrome, most common cause of inherited mental retardation (among X-linked disorders), intellectual disability, and autism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bloom syndrome: features are:

 

  • Short stature
  • Sun sensitive rash over the nose and nose and cheeks
  • Immune deficiency 
  • Insulin resistance that resembles Type 2 Diabetes

 

The question doesn’t mention such feature. Therefore, bloom syndrome is not the right answer

 

Option C. Angelman syndrome: remember “angel is the mother” therefore, in this syndrome maternal gene is deleted. It is one of the examples of uniparental disomy. The clinical features are:

 

 

  1. Maternal gene is deleted
  2. Paternal gene is doubled
  3. Dev delay
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Microcephaly
  6. Hyperactive
  7. Spontaneous laughter - Happy Puppets
  8. Hypertonia
  9. UBE3A GENE ON Chr 15 is defective/absent

 

Option D. fragile x syndrome: it is the second most common non preventable cause of mental retardation. The features are:

 

  1. Male patient
  2. Large ears
  3. Large testes
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Nose will NOT be large

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cri-du-chat syndrome is identified by a partial deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5, leading to distinctive clinical features such as a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and intellectual disability.

choices.text: Test stool for giardia and give antibiotics
Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant born to an HIV-positive mother presents with recurrent diarrhea. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR

 

In the given clinical scenario, it is important to establish or rule out a diagnosis of HIV infection before evaluating for secondary infections. Therefore, the next best step is to obtain a dried spot sample for HIV DNA PCR. AIDS enteropathy, a syndrome of malabsorption with partial villous atrophy not associated with a specific pathogen, has been postulated to be a result of direct HIV infection of the gut.

 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in infants born to HIV-infected mothers is done using various methods, including HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program now uses an HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample.

 

Infants born to HIV-positive mothers should be exclusively breastfed or fed with replacement feeds exclusively until 6 months of age. Infants should also receive AR prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine.

 

It is common for HIV-infected infants to experience gastrointestinal tract involvement, with bacteria (Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella, Mycobacterium avium complex), protozoa (Giardia, Cryptosporidium, Isospora, microsporidia), viruses (CMV, HSV, rotavirus), and fungi (Candida) being common pathogens. MAC and protozoal infections tend to be the most severe and prolonged in children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Test stool for giardiasis and give antibiotics: This is not the preferred immediate next step. First, the diagnosis of HIV infection should be established before treating secondary infections.

 

Option C. Antibody tests for HIV: Antibody tests for HIV are not useful in establishing the diagnosis of HIV infection in infants. This is because all infants born to HIV-infected mothers test antibodies positive at birth due to the passive transfer of maternal HIV antibodies across the placenta. It can be used as a diagnostic tool after 18 months of age.

 

Option D. Aerobic culture: Aerobic culture is not used for the diagnosis of HIV infection. It is more relevant for identifying bacterial infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The next best step in diagnosing HIV in infants born to HIV-positive mothers is to perform an HIV DNA PCR test using a dried blood spot sample.

choices.text: Spinal muscular atrophy

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the appearance of enlarged calves, as shown in the image, typically seen in a child? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Muscular dystrophy

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows enlargement of the calves (pseudohypertrophy) along with wasting of thigh muscles, which are classic features of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). This condition is the most common form of muscular dystrophy. The pseudohypertrophy is caused by hypertrophy of some muscle fibers, infiltration of muscle by fat, and proliferation of collagen. DMD is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the gene responsible for producing dystrophin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinal muscular atrophy - This condition primarily involves muscle weakness and atrophy but does not typically present with calf pseudohypertrophy.

 

Option B. Myopathy - General term for muscle disease; specific types may present with muscle weakness but not necessarily with calf pseudohypertrophy.

 

Option D. Peripheral neuropathy - This condition involves damage to peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and atrophy but not pseudohypertrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enlargement of the calves, known as pseudohypertrophy, along with muscle wasting, is a classic feature of Duchenne muscular dystrophy

questions.text: Which one among the following has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rubella


Rubella, also known as German measles, has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission compared to the other infections listed. While rubella can be transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, and can lead to significant complications such as congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), the overall risk of transmission at the time of birth is lower than for the other infections listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother has an active infection at the time of delivery. Neonatal herpes can result in severe outcomes, including encephalitis and disseminated disease.

 

Perinatal transmission: 25-60% with active genital lesions

Highest risk with primary maternal infection at delivery

Can cause severe neonatal herpes (encephalitis, disseminated disease)

Cesarean section recommended if active lesions

 

Option B. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is the most common congenital infection and has a significant risk of perinatal transmission. 

Perinatal transmission: 30-40% through breast milk, cervical secretions

Can occur through birth canal or postpartum

Usually asymptomatic in term infants

More severe in preterm infants
 

It can lead to a range of outcomes from asymptomatic infection to severe neurological impairment.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) has a high risk of perinatal transmission, particularly if the mother is HBeAg positive. Without appropriate prophylaxis, many infants born to HBV-positive mothers will become chronically infected.

 

Perinatal transmission: 70-90% if mother is HBeAg positive

20-30% if HBeAg negative

Occurs during delivery through blood/body fluids

Without prophylaxis, leads to chronic infection in 90% of infected infants
 

Educational Objective:
 

Rubella has the lowest risk of perinatal transmission among the options listed, though it can still cause serious fetal complications if transmitted during pregnancy.

questions.text: Choose the correct order of suctioning during neonatal resuscitation? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mouth-nose


During neonatal resuscitation, suctioning is performed to clear the airway of the newborn to ensure effective breathing. The correct order for suctioning is mouth first, followed by the nose. This order is crucial because suctioning the nose first could cause the newborn to gasp and potentially aspirate any fluids or secretions present in the mouth.

 

Technical Details:

 

  • The suction catheter typically used is 12 or 14 French, and the suction pressure is maintained between 80-100 mmHg.
  • Tracheal suctioning has become obsolete and is no longer routinely performed unless specifically indicated.
  • Suctioning of the esophagus and stomach is avoided as it can stimulate the vagal nerve, leading to apnea and/or bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nose-mouth: This is incorrect as suctioning the nose first increases the risk of aspiration.

 

Option C. Mouth-nose-oesophagus: Suctioning the esophagus is not part of the standard procedure and can cause complications such as vagal stimulation.

 

Option D. Trachea-nose-mouth: Tracheal suctioning is obsolete and not recommended in modern neonatal resuscitation protocols.

 

Educational Objective:


During neonatal resuscitation, the mouth should be suctioned before the nose to minimize the risk of aspiration and ensure a clear airway for effective ventilation.

questions.text: The following finding can be seen in: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parvovirus B19 infection

 

The 5th disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is caused by Parvovirus B19. It is a common childhood viral infection characterized by a "slapped-cheek" rash.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Molluscum contagiosum: This is not correct. Molluscum contagiosum is a viral skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option C. HFMD (Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease): HFMD is caused by enteroviruses, primarily Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus 71. It does not cause the 5th disease.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is not caused by Parvovirus B19. It is an inflammatory condition of blood vessels, and its etiology is not related to the virus responsible for the 5th disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize the causative agent of the 5th disease (erythema infectiosum) as Parvovirus B19. Understand the clinical manifestations of the 5th disease, including the characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash, and differentiate it from other childhood viral infections such as HFMD and conditions like Kawasaki disease and molluscum contagiosum.

choices.text: Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.text: All the following PFT findings in a child are suggestive of asthma except? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Day- night variation of FEV1 > 12%

 

A day-night variation of FEV1 > 12%, is not a standard measure used in the diagnosis of asthma. While diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow (PEF) is often used to monitor asthma control, it is not specifically measured by FEV1, and a >12% variation in FEV1 between day and night is not typically used as a diagnostic criterion for asthma.

 

Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) are essential in diagnosing and managing asthma, particularly in identifying airflow obstruction and its reversibility. Specific findings on PFTs suggestive of asthma include:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation: An increase in FEV1 (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second) by more than 15% after the administration of a bronchodilator like salbutamol is indicative of reversible airway obstruction, which is characteristic of asthma.

 

Option B. FEV1/FVC< 80%: A FEV1/FVC (Forced Vital Capacity) ratio of less than 80% is suggestive of obstructive lung disease, including asthma. This ratio decreases because of the increased airway resistance in asthmatic patients.

 

Option D. Decrease in FEV1>12% after exercise: A decrease in FEV1 by more than 15% after exercise is a sign of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, a common feature of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increase in FEV1 > 12% after bronchodilator use and a FEV1/FVC ratio < 80% are key PFT findings suggestive of asthma.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP)

 

In the given clinical scenario, the boy exhibits typical signs and symptoms of Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP). HSP is a type of small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects children. It is characterized by the presence of a purpuric rash, as well as arthritis and abdominal pain. Additionally, approximately 50% of patients with HSP develop renal complications that can range from asymptomatic microscopic hematuria to severe, progressive glomerulonephritis.

 

In patients with HSP, the onset of nephritis typically follows the development of the rash. The pathogenesis of HSP nephritis is believed to be associated with the deposition of polymeric immunoglobulin A (IgA) in glomeruli.

 

  • Here are some common types of vasculitis that can affect children.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE typically presents with a butterfly malar rash over the face, especially involving the nasolabial folds. It also includes systemic symptoms like fever, joint pain, and renal involvement, but the presentation and rash pattern differ from HSP.

 

Option C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP presents with petechiae all over the body due to thrombocytopenia, and the patient typically has a low platelet count. Peripheral smear usually shows an increase in megakaryocytes.

 

Option D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is a medium vessel vasculitis that presents with fever, abdominal pain, skin changes like livedo reticularis, muscle and joint pain, and neuropathy. It does not typically present with the purpuric rash and renal involvement seen in HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is characterized by a purpuric rash, arthritis, abdominal pain, and renal complications such as hematuria and proteinuria, typically following the rash development.

choices.text: Serum ferritin levels
T2 MRI of the liver
Liver iron concentration measurement

questions.text: A 9-year-old child with thalassemia is undergoing regular blood transfusions every few weeks. Due to the frequent transfusions, there is concern about the risk of iron overload, which can damage vital organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands. To assess the iron levels in the body, the healthcare provider is planning to conduct appropriate tests. What is the best method to detect iron overload in this child?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Liver iron concentration measurement

 

Explanation:

 

Children with thalassemia who undergo multiple blood transfusions are at significant risk of iron overload, which can lead to damage in the liver, heart, and endocrine glands. Monitoring liver iron concentration is the best method to assess iron overload because it directly indicates total body iron stores.

 

Liver Iron Concentration Measurement:

 

  • Liver Biopsy: An invasive method that measures iron content directly in liver tissue. While it is accurate, it carries risks such as bleeding and discomfort, making it less suitable for regular monitoring.
  • T2 MRI of the Liver: A non-invasive, preferred method for assessing liver iron concentration. This imaging technique is reliable, safe, and accurate for ongoing monitoring of iron levels without the risks associated with liver biopsy. T2 MRI is often used in clinical practice due to its ability to provide detailed measurements of liver iron, guiding management and treatment.

 

Other Relevant Tests for Monitoring Iron Overload:

 

  • Serum Ferritin Levels: Can be used every three months to monitor iron levels but is not as specific or reliable as liver iron concentration measurements because it can be influenced by inflammation and other factors.
  • T2 MRI of the Heart: This test measures cardiac iron levels but is not the primary method for assessing overall iron overload.
  • Echocardiography: Primarily used to assess heart function and detect complications due to iron overload but does not measure iron directly.

 

Management of Iron Overload:

 

Chelation Therapy: Essential for removing excess iron from the body. Common agents include deferoxamine (administered intravenously or subcutaneously), deferasirox, and deferiprone (both oral medications), which help prevent organ damage by binding excess iron for excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Liver iron concentration measurement, especially through T2 MRI, is the best method to detect iron overload in children with thalassemia undergoing frequent blood transfusions. It accurately reflects total body iron stores, allowing for effective monitoring and management of iron levels to prevent organ damage.

questions.text: Adrenocorticotropic hormone is the drug of choice in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) West syndrome

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

 

  • West syndrome is a severe generalised epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of:
    • Infantile spasm
    • Developmental regression
    • Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

 

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes.

 

Treatment of West syndrome includes:

 

  • ACTH
  • Vigabatrin when associated with tuberous sclerosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: Young adults who have juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME) commonly experience myoclonic jerks in the morning. Valproate is helpful in treating benign myoclonic epilepsy, whereas levetiracetam is helpful in treating severe myoclonic epilepsies.

 

Option B. Rolandic epilepsy: Rolandic epilepsy is benign epilepsy seen in children. They present at night or while awakening.

 

Option D. Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS): Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare but severe form of childhood epilepsy characterized by a triad of multiple seizure types, characteristic EEG findings, and intellectual impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) is the drug of choice in West syndrome.

questions.text: Which pattern of inheritance does the pedigree chart denote? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autosomal-recessive disorder

 

The pedigree chart shown suggests an autosomal-recessive disorder based on several key observations:

 

  1. Horizontal Pattern: The affected individuals appear in the same generation but are not present in the preceding or subsequent generations. This pattern is characteristic of autosomal-recessive inheritance, where the disorder tends to skip generations unless both parents carry the recessive allele.
  2. Unaffected Parents: Both parents of affected individuals are unaffected, suggesting they are carriers of the recessive allele. In autosomal-recessive inheritance, an individual must inherit two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) to express the disorder.
  3. Carrier Frequency: According to autosomal-recessive inheritance patterns, when both parents are carriers, there is a 25% chance that their offspring will have the disorder (inherit two mutated genes), a 50% chance that the offspring will be carriers (inherit one mutated gene and one normal gene), and a 25% chance that the offspring will have a normal genotype (inherit two normal genes).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal-dominant disorder: This pattern typically shows affected individuals in every generation, with both males and females equally likely to inherit the disorder. Affected individuals have a 50% chance of passing the disorder to their offspring, regardless of the other parent's genotype.

 

Option B. X-linked dominant disorder: This pattern would show affected females more frequently if the father is affected and can appear in every generation. However, affected males would pass the condition to all of their daughters and none of their sons.

 

Option D. X-linked recessive disorder: This pattern is more common in males, as they only have one X chromosome. Carrier females would pass the disorder to 50% of their sons, and 50% of their daughters would be carriers. However, in this pedigree, both males and females are affected equally, and the pattern does not suggest an X-linked inheritance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal-recessive disorders are typically characterized by a horizontal pattern of inheritance, where the disorder appears in siblings of the same generation but may skip generations, with unaffected parents often being carriers.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distension. The peripheral smear done is as shown below, and the Mentzer index was found to be less than 13. What are the investigations to be done in this patient? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC)
  2. PT and APTT
  3. Bone marrow
  4. Peripheral blood smear
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 4

 

The clinical presentation, along with the findings of the peripheral blood smear and a Mentzer index of less than 13, suggests a diagnosis of thalassemia.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thalassemia: A hemoglobinopathy characterized by a deficiency in the synthesis of one of the globin chains, either alpha or beta. In beta-thalassemia, there is reduced synthesis of beta chains, leading to decreased levels of hemoglobin A (HbA) and increased levels of HbA2 and HbF.
  • High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC): This test is crucial for diagnosing thalassemia as it can detect changes in hemoglobin levels, specifically the increased levels of HbA2 and HbF that are characteristic of beta-thalassemia. HPLC is sufficient for diagnosis without the need for bone marrow investigations.
  • Peripheral Blood Smear: The smear may reveal aniso-poikilocytosis, target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells, which are indicative of thalassemia.
  • Mentzer Index: The Mentzer index, calculated as MCV/RBC count, helps differentiate thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia. A value of less than 13 suggests thalassemia, while a value greater than 13 suggests iron-deficiency anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

2 (PT and APTT): These tests are not directly relevant for the diagnosis of thalassemia. PT (Prothrombin Time) is used to assess the extrinsic pathway of coagulation, and APTT (Activated Partial Thromboplastin Time) assesses the intrinsic pathway, typically done when bleeding disorders are suspected.

 

3 (Bone Marrow): Bone marrow examination is not necessary in this case as the diagnosis of thalassemia can be made based on HPLC and peripheral smear findings. Bone marrow investigations are more appropriate for cases of pancytopenia or unexplained anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child suspected of having thalassemia, High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) and a peripheral blood smear are key investigations for diagnosis.

questions.text: During the anthropometric evaluation, the height for age of a child is < - 2D. This is most likely due to? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic malnutrition

 

If the height for age of a child is less than -2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population, it is most likely due to chronic malnutrition.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Chronic Malnutrition (Stunting): Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, occurs when a child does not receive adequate nutrition over a prolonged period, especially during the critical first 1,000 days of life (from conception to the child's second birthday). This results in impaired linear growth, making the child shorter than expected for their age. Height for age is the key indicator used to measure stunting.
  • Acute Malnutrition (Wasting): Acute malnutrition, or wasting, is characterized by a rapid loss of weight relative to height. It is usually the result of a recent illness or severe food shortage. Weight for height is the primary measure of wasting, not height for age.
  • Recent Infection: While a recent infection can temporarily affect a child's weight or growth velocity, it does not typically lead to chronic stunting unless the child experiences recurrent infections over a long period.
  • No Malnutrition: If a child's height for age is within the normal range, it indicates adequate nutrition and growth. However, a height for age < -2SD indicates a significant deviation from the norm due to chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute malnutrition: This condition affects the weight for height parameter, indicating a rapid loss of weight rather than a prolonged deficit in linear growth.

 

Option C. Recent infection: Although a recent infection can cause temporary weight loss or affect growth velocity, it is unlikely to result in stunted growth unless the child has had recurrent infections over an extended period.

 

Option D. No malnutrition: A child with a height for age < -2SD cannot be classified as having no malnutrition, as this deviation indicates chronic nutritional deficiencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Height for age < -2SD is indicative of chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, which results from prolonged inadequate nutrition, particularly during the critical early years of a child's life.

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in physiological jaundice? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

 

In physiological jaundice, there is increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine.

 

Physiological jaundice occurs as a result of increased bilirubin production caused by foetal RB destruction, as well as a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. As a result, indirect/unconjugated bilirubin levels would rise. Increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood cause an increase in the production of urobilinogen, which is found in large quantities in the urine. Urine bilirubin is uncommon in this condition.

 

Both physiological jaundice (indirect) and hepatocellular jaundice (direct) can have increased urobilinogen - just through different mechanisms:

  • Physiological: ↑ bilirubin load despite immature conjugation
  • Hepatocellular: ↑ conjugated bilirubin reaching gut despite liver damage


 

 

The following indications are suggestive of pathological jaundice and it warrants further investigations for the cause of jaundice.

 

  1. Jaundice appearing in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  2. A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dl/24hr
  3. Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  4. Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  5. Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  6. Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

 

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

 

When the concentration of unconjugated bilirubin exceeds 20-25mg/dL, bilirubin would penetrate the blood-brain barrier and lead to kernicterus.

 

Phototherapy:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological jaundice is characterized by increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, and the absence of bilirubin in the urine.

questions.text: Sign of effective neonatal resuscitation is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased heart rate

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate. Based on heart rate, the response to newborn resuscitation is evaluated at different stages.

 

  • If the heart rate is under 100, PPV is given, SPO2 is monitored, and sufficient breathing is guaranteed.
  • Chest compressions are started over the lower portion of the sternum at a pace of 90 compressions per minute if the heart rate is below 60. The ventilation to compression ratio is 3 to 1.
  • IV epinephrine is administered if the heart rate is still below 60 despite effective compressions and breathing.


 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colour change: Colour change is not a sign of effective resuscitation.

 

Option B. Bilateral air entry: this feature is checked when we are thinking of pneumothorax or severe pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best indicator of successful newborn resuscitation is a rise in heart rate.

questions.text: A neonate is found to have increased irritability, poor feeding, and 2 episodes of seizures. Lumbar puncture was done and the findings were suggestive of meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

  • Neonatal meningitis is suspected in the given clinical scenario. The most likely causative organism is Streptococcus agalactiae, which is part of group B streptococci.
  • Neonatal meningitis can either have an early or a late start. Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants and is typically caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (primarily S. epidermidis), as well as S. aureus, E. coli, and Klebsiella species. Early-onset meningitis affects newborns within the first 72 hours of life.
  • Group B streptococci are the most common cause of both meningitis and neonatal sepsis, followed by E. coli. However, E. coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Neisseria meningitidis: Asymptomatic meningococcal infections are common. If invasive disease occurs, the clinical spectrum ranges from meningococcal meningitis (which accounts for the majority of cases) to bacteremia without sepsis, meningococcal septicemia with or without meningitis, pneumonia, chronic meningococcemia, and occult bacteremia.

 

Option D. Listeria monocytogenes: Meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes is relatively rare but clinically significant. Infants acquire infection in utero or by inoculation through an infected birth canal. Neonatal listeriosis can be,

 

  • Early-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants less than 5 days old, usually within 1-2 days of birth. Predominantly septicemic form.
  • Late-onset neonatal disease, which occurs in infants >5 days old. Predominantly meningitic form.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Group B Streptococcus (Streptococcus agalactiae) is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, and early recognition and treatment are critical for reducing morbidity and mortality.

questions.text: The following device shown attached to the baby is used in all except: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Measure central cyanosis.

 

The device shown in the image is a pulse oximeter. A pulse oximeter is commonly used to measure the oxygen saturation (SpO2) of the blood and monitor heart rate. While it is useful in many clinical settings, including neonatal care, it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

 

Cyanosis is a clinical sign that appears when there is at least 5 g/dL of deoxygenated hemoglobin in the blood. A pulse oximeter measures oxygen saturation but does not directly assess the color changes in the skin or mucous membranes, which are crucial for identifying cyanosis. Moreover, in conditions like severe anemia, a patient might have a low oxygen saturation without appearing cyanosed.

 

However, measuring central cyanosis requires clinical observation and is not reliably detected by a pulse oximeter. Therefore, a pulse oximeter is not used to measure central cyanosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Uses of a Pulse Oximeter:

 

Option A. In CPR: Pulse oximeters are used to monitor oxygenation and the effectiveness of chest compressions and ventilation during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.

 

Option B. To know about apnea: Pulse oximeters can indicate apnea by detecting bradycardia and desaturation episodes.

 

Option C. In neonatal resuscitation: Pulse oximeters are vital for assessing the newborn's oxygenation status during resuscitation and adjusting oxygen therapy as needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pulse oximeter is useful in various neonatal and resuscitation settings to monitor oxygen saturation and heart rate, but it is not reliable for detecting central cyanosis.

choices.text: Urinary tract infection

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents due to continuous dribbling of urine since birth. Despite this, she can void normally when using the toilet. Her parents report that she has never been completely dry, and this has significantly impacted her daily activities. There is no history of urinary tract infections, recent trauma, or surgeries. Physical examination reveals normal external genitalia with no signs of infection or abnormalities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Ectopic ureter

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of continuous dribbling of urine from birth despite normal voiding suggests an ectopic ureter. An ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly resulting from improper positioning of the ureter during fetal development. In females, the ectopic ureter often drains outside the bladder, commonly inserting into the vagina or distal urethra, leading to persistent urinary incontinence.

 

Ectopic Ureter: Typically presents with continuous urine leakage because the ureter bypasses the normal continence mechanisms of the bladder.

 

This condition often goes undetected until later in childhood, as affected individuals can still void normally with the normally positioned ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Vesicoureteral reflux: This condition involves the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the ureters, which can lead to recurrent urinary tract infections. It does not typically cause continuous urine dribbling.

 

Option B) Urinary tract infection: UTIs present with symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency, but they do not cause continuous dribbling since birth.

 

Option D) Bladder exstrophy: A severe congenital condition where the bladder is exposed outside the body, usually diagnosed at birth. It presents with visible bladder abnormalities, which are not seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An ectopic ureter should be suspected in a young female presenting with continuous urinary dribbling since birth despite normal voiding. It results from an abnormal ureteral insertion, often requiring imaging studies for diagnosis and surgical intervention for correction.

questions.text: Identify the vitamin which when deficient can lead to neonatal seizures? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pyridoxine

 

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) deficiency is a well-known cause of refractory seizures in neonates and infants. Pyridoxine is crucial for the synthesis of neurotransmitters such as gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), which plays a key role in inhibiting neural activity. A deficiency in pyridoxine can disrupt neurotransmitter balance, leading to seizures that are often difficult to control with standard anticonvulsant therapy.

 

Neonatal seizures caused by pyridoxine deficiency typically present within the first few hours to days of life. These seizures are often clonic in nature and may involve multiple foci. The underlying cause of pyridoxine-dependent seizures is typically a mutation in the ALDH7A1 gene, which impairs the ability of an enzyme to break down I-alpha-aminoadipic semialdehyde, leading to a buildup of toxic substances that affect brain function.

 

Prompt administration of pyridoxine can rapidly resolve the seizures, making it an essential diagnostic and therapeutic consideration in neonates presenting with unexplained seizures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiamine: Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with neurological disorders like Wernicke's encephalopathy and beriberi, but it is not typically associated with neonatal seizures.

 

Option C. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) deficiency can cause ariboflavinosis, characterized by sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, but it is not commonly linked to neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Pantothenic acid: Pantothenic acid (Vitamin B5) deficiency is extremely rare and is associated with symptoms like fatigue, depression, and irritability, but it does not typically cause neonatal seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pyridoxine deficiency can cause refractory seizures in neonates, and recognizing this condition is crucial because these seizures can be rapidly treated with pyridoxine supplementation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Measles

 

Based on the given information, the most likely diagnosis for the 3-year-old male with buccal mucosa findings followed by a rash after three days is Measles.

 

  • Measles is a viral illness that commonly affects children. It typically starts with flu-like symptoms such as fever, cough, runny nose, and red, watery eyes.
  • One of the hallmark signs of measles is the presence of Koplik spots, which are small, white, grain-like lesions that appear on the buccal mucosa.
  • A rash usually follows the appearance of Koplik spots. This rash typically starts on the face and neck and then spreads to the rest of the body.
  • If you suspect that a child has measles, it is essential to isolate them and refer them to a healthcare facility for further evaluation and treatment.
  • Lymphadenopathy may also be present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leukoplakia: Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by white patches on the mucous membranes. It is not associated with fever and rash.

 

Option C. Scarlet fever: Scarlet fever is caused by beta-hemolytic streptococci and presents with a URI (upper respiratory infection) and a sandpaper-like rash. It does not have Koplik spots.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash, and conjunctivitis but lacks Koplik spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

questions.text: The following image depicts which of the following diseases? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scabies

 

Special linear tunnel like lesion called Burrow; is depicted in the image given and it is seen in Scabies. Burrow is the pathognomonic lesion of scabies. Usually, S shaped.

 

Scabies is an ectoparasitic infestation caused by the Sarcoptes scabei var hominis.

 

Itch mite

 

Sarcoptes scabei

 

 

  • The incubation period of scabies typically lasts 3-4 weeks (21-28 days). However, in previously cured individuals, reinfection can lead to immediate symptoms.
  • The most common symptom associated with scabies is nocturnal pruritus, and the itching worsens at night and in warm conditions.
  • Scabies is considered a water-washed disease, meaning it is linked to inadequate personal hygiene and limited access to clean water.
  • Distinctive signs of scabies include intense itching and the presence of shallow burrows.

 

Burrows in scabies are typically found in the stratum corneum as depicted in the below image.

 

 

In most people the trails of the burrowing mites appear brownish linear or s shaped tracks in the skin & occur as a result of excavation of the adult mite in the epidermis.

 

S-shaped track, pointed with black arrows in the below image:

 

 

  • Burrows are absent in animal scabies.
  • Lesions are found in the Circle of Hebra (imaginary line formed by connecting the sites of involvement in scabies like, web spaces, feet, ventral wrists, elbows, cack, breasts, buttocks & external genitals).
  • A single overnight application of 5% permethrin cream from neck to toe in adults & from head to toe in children is the drug of choice for the treatment of scabies in all ages including infants (at least 2 months old & pregnant women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ichthyosis:

 

  • Ichthyosis is a group of skin disorders characterized by dry, scaly skin.
  • It does not have burrowing mites, hence no burrows are seen.
  • It generally presents with large scales, especially on the lower limbs.

 

Option C. Contact dermatitis:

 

  • This is an allergic or irritant-induced skin inflammation.
  • It manifests as red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with vesicles or blisters.
  • There's no mite involvement or formation of burrows in contact dermatitis.

 

Option D. Urticaria:

 

  • Commonly known as hives, urticaria presents as raised, itchy, red lesions on the skin.
  • It is an allergic reaction and can be triggered by a variety of factors.
  • Urticaria does not involve mites or the creation of burrows in the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of linear tunnel like lesions called as burrows in the stratum corneum of the skin, as depicted in the image, is a hallmark sign of scabies, distinguishing it from other skin conditions like ichthyosis, contact dermatitis, and urticaria.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 34 page no 34.39-34.47

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no: 3274

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and full course of vaccine

questions.text: A young male came to the hospital with a clean-cut wound without any bleeding. The patient received a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. What is the best management for this patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Single-dose tetanus toxoid

 

The patient presents with a clean-cut wound and has a history of receiving a full course of tetanus vaccination 10 years ago. Based on the guidelines for tetanus prophylaxis, the appropriate management for this patient falls under the category where the patient has received a complete course of tetanus vaccination more than 5 years ago but less than 10 years ago.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Management of Tetanus-Prone Wounds:

 

 

CC = Complete course; TIG = Tetanus Immunoglobulin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a growth factor promoting proto-oncogene?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) TGF-beta

 

Transforming Growth Factor-beta (TGF-beta) does not promote proto-oncogenes. Instead, TGF-beta plays a crucial role in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing by promoting the deposition of fibrous tissue. TGF-beta acts similarly to interleukin-10, reducing inflammation and aiding in tissue repair. Unlike other growth factors such as TGF-alpha, PDGF, and FGF, which are involved in cell proliferation and can promote proto-oncogenes, TGF-beta primarily functions to control and reduce inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TGF-alpha: Incorrect. TGF-alpha is a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is involved in cell proliferation.

 

Option B. PDGF: Incorrect. Platelet-Derived Growth Factor (PDGF) is a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is significant in the pathogenesis of brain tumors and other cell growth processes.

 

Option C. FGF: Incorrect. Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF) is another growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes and is involved in various cellular processes, including cell growth and development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TGF-beta is not a growth factor that promotes proto-oncogenes; instead, it is involved in down-regulating the inflammatory response and facilitating wound healing.

questions.text: The drug of choice for insomnia in blind people is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tasimelteon

 

Tasimelteon and Ramelteon are melatonin agonists. Tasimelteon is used for the treatment of insomnia in blind persons, whereas Ramelteon is used for the treatment of jet lag and also used for sleep induction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Latanoprostene: Is not relevant to the treatment of insomnia. It is a medication used to reduce intraocular pressure in patients with glaucoma or ocular hypertension.

 

Option B. Zerviate: Is an antihistamine eye drop used for the treatment of ocular itching associated with allergic conjunctivitis, not for insomnia.

 

Option D. Ramelteon: Is also a melatonin receptor agonist used for the treatment of insomnia, specifically for difficulties with sleep onset. It is not specifically indicated for Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder in blind individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tasimelteon is the drug of choice for treating insomnia in blind individuals due to its effectiveness in regulating the sleep-wake cycle by acting as a melatonin receptor agonist, particularly in those with Non-24-Hour Sleep-Wake Disorder.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with dragging pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is massive splenomegaly. Peripheral smear shows leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes and basophils. Which of the following translocation is seen in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) t (9:22)

 

Massive splenomegaly and a peripheral smear showing leukocytosis with increased myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and basophils are symptoms of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). This condition is characterized by a translocation between t (9;22).

 

CML is classified as a myeloproliferative neoplasm. It is caused by a translocation between BCR (on chromosome 22) and ABL (on chromosome 9) to form a fusion gene. It leads to the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which is characteristic of CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. t (8;22): Associated with Burkitt lymphoma involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8.

 

Option C. t (15;17): Associated with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), involving the PML and RARA genes.

 

Option D. t (8;14): Also associated with Burkitt lymphoma, involving the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8 and the IgH locus on chromosome 14.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The translocation t(9;22) is characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and results in the formation of the Philadelphia chromosome, which produces the BCR-ABL fusion gene responsible for the disease's pathogenesis.

questions.text: A neonate presents with cicatrizing skin lesions all over the body and limb hypoplasia. An MRI of the brain shows diffuse cerebral atrophy, and an ophthalmologic evaluation reveals chorioretinitis. Which test is most likely to be positive in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Anti-VZV antibody

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of cicatrizing skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, cerebral atrophy, and chorioretinitis suggests congenital varicella syndrome. This condition is caused by an intrauterine infection with the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Detection of anti-VZV antibodies in the patient would confirm this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HCMV antibodies - These are associated with congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which presents differently.

 

Option B. Anti-toxoplasma antibodies - These are associated with congenital toxoplasmosis, characterized by different clinical features.

 

Option D. Anti-rubella antibody - These are associated with congenital rubella syndrome, which also presents with different symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital varicella syndrome can be diagnosed by the presence of anti-VZV antibodies, which correlate with characteristic features such as cicatrizing skin lesions, limb hypoplasia, cerebral atrophy, and chorioretinitis.

questions.text: During her pregnancy, the lady regularly cleans her cat's litter to prevent toxoplasma infection. What is the specific infective stage of this organism found in the cat feces? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oocysts

 

Oocysts are the infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii that are shed in the feces of infected cats. These oocysts are highly resistant and can survive in the environment for extended periods, becoming infectious to other hosts, including humans, once they sporulate. When a pregnant woman comes into contact with these oocysts, there is a risk of transmitting the infection to the fetus, which can lead to serious congenital abnormalities.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradyzoites are the form of Toxoplasma that are found within tissue cysts in intermediate hosts.

 

Option B. Tissue cysts, containing bradyzoites, are found in intermediate hosts such as rodents and birds, and not in cat feces.

 

Option C. Tachyzoites are the rapidly multiplying form of the parasite that disseminates throughout the host's tissues during acute infection but are not the form found in cat feces.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The specific infective stage of Toxoplasma gondii found in cat feces is the oocyst, which poses a risk of infection if ingested.

questions.text: A patient with a history of a backache for 10 days, has now presented with difficulty in micturition and defecation. There was no history of a cough or fever previously. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cauda-Equina syndrome

 

Spinal cord ends at L1. Hence to accommodate the mismatch between vertebra and cord, the conus is formed from T12-L2 vertebral level housing the sacral portion of the cord. The lumbosacral roots descend downwards from conus and exit the corresponding foramina.

 

Sacral (S2,3,4) are responsible for sensations of the bladder wall. Hence injury leads to absent sensation and bladder distension with dribbling of urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pott's Spine: Incorrect because Pott's disease (tuberculosis of the spine) typically presents with chronic back pain associated with systemic symptoms like fever, night sweats, and weight loss due to the infection.

 

Option B. Guillain Barre Syndrome: Guillain Barre Syndrome primarily presents with ascending paralysis starting from the feet upwards, and sphincter involvement is rare, especially as an initial symptom.

 

Option D. Multiple Sclerosis: Incorrect because Multiple Sclerosis involves demyelination primarily affecting the brain and spinal cord but typically causes chronic, rather than acute, symptoms, and would not likely present with acute bladder and bowel dysfunction without other neurological signs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cauda Equina Syndrome presents with acute lower back pain and severe disturbances in bladder and bowel control due to compression of the nerve roots in the lumbar and sacral areas, requiring urgent medical attention to prevent permanent damage.

 

Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Diseases of spinal Cord/Chap 442

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in pompe’s disease is: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alpha 1, 4 glucosidase

 

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), an enzyme involved in the breakdown of glycogen. Pompe's disease is a lysosomal storage disorder characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Glucose 6 phosphatase: This is not the correct enzyme. Glucose 6 phosphatase deficiency is associated with von Gierke's disease, a glycogen storage disorder. It primarily affects the liver and kidney.

 

Option C. Muscle phosphorylase: Muscle phosphorylase is associated with McArdle's disease, a glycogen storage disorder affecting skeletal muscles. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Option D. Phosphofructokinase: Phosphofructokinase is associated with Tarui's disease, another glycogen storage disorder. It is not the enzyme deficient in Pompe's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the enzymatic basis of Pompe's disease, recognizing that it is caused by a deficiency of alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase). Be aware of the clinical manifestations and biochemical abnormalities associated with Pompe's disease, which is characterized by the accumulation of glycogen in various tissues, particularly in muscles.

questions.text: Which vaccine among the options is not recommended for use during pregnancy? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Varicella

 

The Varicella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women because it is a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines contain weakened forms of the virus, which can potentially cross the placenta and infect the fetus, leading to congenital infection or other complications. The primary concern is that the live virus, although weakened, may still pose a risk to the developing fetus.

 

Live vaccines are generally avoided during pregnancy to minimize any potential risks to the fetus. Pregnant women are advised to receive inactivated vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens and are considered safer for both the mother and the unborn child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A:  The Hepatitis A vaccine is an inactivated (killed) vaccine. It is generally considered safe during pregnancy and can be administered if the benefits outweigh the risks, especially if the woman is at high risk for Hepatitis A infection.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B:  The Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant vaccine, which does not contain live virus. It is safe to use during pregnancy and is recommended for pregnant women who are at risk of Hepatitis B infection.

 

Option C. Rabies:  The Rabies vaccine is an inactivated vaccine. It is considered safe during pregnancy and should be administered if there is a risk of rabies exposure, as the disease itself is fatal if not treated promptly.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a painful and growing swelling on the parietal region of the head. The parents report that the child had a fall one year ago, resulting in a parietal bone fracture. Since then, they have noticed that the swelling has progressively increased in size. The child has not had any recent trauma, and there are no signs of fever or infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Leptomeningeal cyst

 

Explanation:

 

The condition described is consistent with a growing fracture, also known as a traumatic leptomeningeal cyst or encephalocele cyst. Growing fractures occur when a skull fracture with an associated dural tear fails to heal properly, leading to progressive enlargement due to herniation of brain tissue, cerebrospinal fluid, or a leptomeningeal cyst.

 

Mechanism of Growing Fracture:

 

Skull fractures with dural tears may not heal correctly, allowing brain tissue, dilated ventricles, or a leptomeningeal cyst to herniate through the defect. This condition is known as a growing skull fracture.

 

Clinical Features:

 

Commonly affects children younger than 3 years old.

 

The condition is usually detected within a year of an acute head injury, presenting as localized swelling or a palpable skull defect that increases in size over time.

 

If left untreated, the condition can present later with symptoms such as headaches, seizures, or neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Subdural hematoma: Typically presents with acute neurological symptoms and is not characterized by progressive swelling over time.

 

Option B) Epidermoid cyst: A benign, slow-growing cyst that does not typically present with a history of head trauma or progressive skull enlargement.

 

Option D) Scalp abscess: Usually associated with infection, pain, and tenderness, and would not be related to a history of previous skull fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growing fractures should be suspected in young children presenting with a progressively enlarging swelling at the site of a previous skull fracture. Early diagnosis and management are essential to prevent long-term neurological complications such as seizures and other deficits.

choices.text: Hydralazine - heart failure
Atenolol - hemolytic anemia
Aliskiren - hypokalemia

questions.text: Identify the correct match, regarding the drug and its adverse effect?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Verapamil – constipation


The correct match regarding the drug and its adverse effect (read carefully, they have not asked the indication) is verapamil causes constipation.

 

Verapamil is a Non DHP calcium channel blocker. It can cause constipation as its side effect.


Other Options:


Option A. Hydralazine is a vasodilator which can cause drug-induced lupus. It does not cause heart failure as an adverse effect, rather It is used in treatment of heart failure.


Option B. Atenolol is a cardio selective beta blocker. Bradycardia can be seen as a side effect, not hemolytic anemia. Hemolytic anemia is a side effect of methyl dopa.


Option C. Aliskiren is a direct renin inhibitor. The side effect of aliskiren is hyperkalemia and not hypokalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Verapamil, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, is associated with constipation as a common adverse effect. Other drugs and their incorrect matches in this context include hydralazine (which can cause drug-induced lupus), atenolol (which does not cause hemolytic anemia), and aliskiren (which can cause hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia).

questions.text: Which of the following is normally seen in lumbar spine? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lordosis

 

Explanation:

 

Lordosis refers to the inward (anterior) curvature of the spine. It's the normal anatomical curvature seen in the lumbar (lower back) and cervical (neck) regions. In the lumbar region, lordosis allows for an upright posture and helps to evenly distribute the body's weight and the forces exerted on the spine. While a certain degree of lumbar lordosis is normal and healthy, excessive lordosis (often called "swayback") can lead to pain and other issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scoliosis: Scoliosis refers to a lateral (side-to-side) curvature of the spine. While any part of the spine can be affected, scoliosis most commonly develops in the thoracic (upper/mid back) and/or lumbar (lower back) regions. It's important to note that while scoliosis can affect the lumbar spine, it is not the normal anatomical curvature for that region. Instead, it's a pathological condition which can be idiopathic (most common, especially in adolescents), congenital, or secondary to other conditions.

 

Option B. Kyphosis: Kyphosis describes a forward (anterior) rounding or curvature of the spine, producing a "hunchback" appearance. The normal anatomical region that displays kyphosis is the thoracic spine (upper/mid back). When present in the lumbar spine, it is considered pathological and is usually secondary to conditions like osteoporosis (which causes compression fractures), degenerative diseases, or other spine disorders.

 

Option D. Recurvatum: Recurvatum typically refers to a backward bending or hyperextension of a joint. While this term can be applied to various joints in the body, it's most commonly associated with the knee joint, where the knee bends backward excessively. It doesn't directly pertain to the natural anatomical curvatures of the spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adults,

 

  • The cervical curve is a lordosis (convex forwards),
  • The thoracic curve is a kyphosis (convex dorsally),
  • The lumbar curve is also a lordosis,
  • The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth have a lesser risk of later sequelae.
  2. 20-40% are symptomatic at birth.
  3. In developing countries, the rate of transmission of CMV infection to the infant is more common from primary maternal infection than reactivation.
  4. Diagnosis by urine specimen at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 3

 

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a common congenital infection, and understanding the nuances of its transmission, diagnosis, and clinical implications is important.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Congenital CMV Infection:
    • Transmission: Congenital CMV infection can occur from either primary maternal infection (which is when the mother is infected with CMV for the first time during pregnancy) or from reactivation of a prior CMV infection in the mother. The risk of transmission to the fetus is significantly higher in cases of primary maternal infection (around 30%) compared to reactivation (about 1-2%). In developing countries, the prevalence of CMV reactivation is higher, but primary infection remains the more significant source of transmission to the fetus.
    • Asymptomatic vs. Symptomatic: The majority of neonates with congenital CMV are asymptomatic at birth, and these asymptomatic infants have a lower risk of developing long-term sequelae such as sensorineural hearing loss compared to those who are symptomatic at birth.
    • Clinical Presentation: About 10% of neonates with congenital CMV infection are symptomatic at birth. Symptoms can include hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rash, jaundice, chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and thrombocytopenia. These symptoms are associated with a higher risk of long-term complications.
    • Diagnosis: CMV infection can be diagnosed by detecting the virus in urine, saliva, or blood within the first three weeks of life. Diagnosis at four weeks, as mentioned in option 4, is less likely to be reliable because it may represent postnatal infection rather than congenital infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (1, 2): The percentage of neonates symptomatic at birth is around 10%, not 20-40%.

 

Option C (2, 4): The diagnosis by urine specimen at four weeks is not ideal, and the percentage of symptomatic neonates at birth is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonates who are asymptomatic at birth from congenital CMV infection have a lower risk of long-term sequelae, and transmission is more common from primary maternal infection than from reactivation, especially in developing countries.

choices.text: Flap closure of foramen ovale
Patent ductus arteriosus
Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
Premature closure of the ductus venosus

questions.text: A 25-year primigravida is on indomethacin (25mg TDS) for polyhydramnios till 35 weeks. What abnormality can the fetus have if she goes into labor now? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 

Explanation:

 

Indomethacin and Fetal Effects:

 

  • Indomethacin is a non-selective cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor used in obstetrics primarily for two indications:
    • Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid.
    • Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • Mechanism: Indomethacin works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are important for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus.
  • Risks: When used beyond 32 weeks of gestation, indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus, leading to complications such as:
    • Pulmonary hypertension
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy
    • Heart failure

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flap closure of foramen ovale: The foramen ovale normally closes soon after birth when the pressure in the left atrium exceeds the pressure in the right atrium. Indomethacin does not affect the closure of the foramen ovale.

 

Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a condition where the ductus arteriosus remains open after birth. Indomethacin is actually used to treat PDA by promoting its closure, not causing it.

 

Option D. Premature closure of the ductus venosus: The ductus venosus allows oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to bypass the liver and flow directly into the inferior vena cava. Indomethacin does not influence the closure of the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if used beyond 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 679, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy, and a peripheral smear showing the presence of smudge cells suggest a diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Immunophenotyping using flow cytometry is the investigation done to arrive at the diagnosis. The classical immunophenotypic feature of CLL is CD 19+, CD20+, CD 23+, CD5+ and surface immunoglobulins of various classes, monoclonal light chains (λ or κ type).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): While PCR can be useful in certain hematologic malignancies for detecting specific genetic mutations, it is not the first-line diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH can be used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL but is not the primary diagnostic tool.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can provide additional prognostic information by identifying chromosomal abnormalities but is typically done after confirming the diagnosis with flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient suspected of having Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL), Flow cytometry is the key diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

 

Ref: Robins Pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 1114

questions.text: Drug with mechanism of action are given in two columns. Which of the following is the correct match?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-E

 

The correct matches between the drugs and their mechanisms of action are as follows:

  1. Omalizumab - Anti-IgE (1-C)
    • Indication: Omalizumab is used in the treatment of bronchial asthma. It works by binding to IgE, which plays a key role in allergic reactions.
  2. Itolizumab - Anti-CD 6 (2-A)
    • Indication: Itolizumab is a new drug used for psoriasis. It targets CD6, a molecule involved in T-cell activation.
  3. Daclizumab - Anti-CD 25 (3-B)
    • Indication: Daclizumab acts as an IL-2 receptor antagonist by binding to CD25, which is part of the IL-2 receptor. It is used as an immunosuppressant.
  4. Belimumab - Anti-B lymphocyte stimulator (BlyS) (4-E)
    • Indication: Belimumab is used for the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It inhibits B-lymphocyte stimulator, which is involved in the survival of B cells.

 

Educational objective:

 

 

Reference: KDT 8TH/251-52,943

questions.text:
Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. HIV  
  2. SLE  
  3. CLL  
  4. Hepatitis B
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPG) is seen in HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B.

 

MPGN is caused due to immune-mediated injury. It often presents with a nephritic-nephrotic picture.

 

The causes of MPGN are as follows:

 

  • Primary MPGN (Idiopathic)
  • Secondary MPGN
  • System lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Alpha 1-antitrypsin deficiency
  • Infections - hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, schistosomiasis, endocarditis, infected ventriculoarterial shunts, chronic visceral abscesses
  • Malignancies - chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

 

MPGN is characterized by the proliferation of cells predominantly in the mesangium and the capillary loops. Hence it is also called mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis.

 

There are 2 types of MPGN:

 

 

  • Duplication of the basement membrane gives a double contour or tram-track appearance. It is especially evident in silver or PAS stains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MPGN can be seen in various conditions, including HIV, SLE, CLL, and Hepatitis B, making it important to consider these diseases in the differential diagnosis of MPGN

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotrans pathological basis of disease 8th edition pg 1777

choices.text: Live virus vaccines are safe and should be administered without restrictions.
All killed vaccines can be given, but live virus vaccines should be administered cautiously.
Live vaccines are recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs like cyclophosphamide.
Household contacts should avoid live vaccines to reduce the risk of illness transmission to the child.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome is brought to the outpatient department for routine vaccination. The child has been on long-term corticosteroid therapy and was recently started on cyclosporine due to frequent relapses. The parents are worried about the safety of vaccinations, given the child’s immunosuppressive medications. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding vaccinations for this child?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) All killed vaccines can be given, but live virus vaccines should be administered cautiously.

 

Explanation:

 

Children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome on corticosteroid and immunosuppressive therapy require careful consideration when it comes to vaccinations:

 

  • Killed Vaccines: All killed vaccines are safe for children receiving corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents and can be administered without restrictions.
  • Live Virus Vaccines: These vaccines should be administered cautiously, particularly in children on corticosteroids. Live vaccines are generally safe for children receiving less than 1 mg/kg of prednisone per day or 2 mg/kg every other day. However, live vaccines are not recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs such as cyclophosphamide, cyclosporine, and similar agents due to the increased risk of severe infection.
  • Prevention of Disease Transmission: Vaccination of healthy household contacts with live vaccines is important to reduce the risk of transmitting infections to the immunosuppressed child. To minimize risk, direct contact with the respiratory and gastrointestinal secretions of vaccinated individuals should be avoided for 3 to 6 weeks following vaccination.
  • Management of Steroid-Dependent Nephrotic Syndrome: The most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease, which typically presents between ages 2 and 6 years. It is treated initially with corticosteroids. For frequent relapses or steroid toxicity, alternative therapies such as Cyclophosphamide, Calcineurin inhibitors (Cyclosporine, Tacrolimus), Mycophenolate, Levamisole, and Rituximab are used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Live virus vaccines are safe and should be administered without restrictions: This is incorrect as live vaccines pose a risk in immunosuppressed children and should be given with caution.

 

Option C) Live vaccines are recommended for children on corticosteroid-sparing drugs like cyclophosphamide: Incorrect, as live vaccines are contraindicated in those on corticosteroid-sparing agents due to the risk of severe infection.

 

Option D) Household contacts should avoid live vaccines to reduce the risk of illness transmission to the child: Incorrect, as vaccinating household contacts with live vaccines helps protect the immunosuppressed child by preventing disease transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In children with steroid-dependent nephrotic syndrome, all killed vaccines can be given safely, while live virus vaccines should be used cautiously based on the child’s specific treatment regimen. Vaccination of household contacts with live vaccines is crucial to prevent the spread of infections to immunosuppressed children.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with tachypnea and mental confusion. His blood sugar is 350 mg/dL, pH - 7.2, HCO3- 10 mEq/L, pCO2 – 25 mmHg. What is the metabolic abnormality? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic acidosis

 

The patient presents with a significantly acidic pH (7.2) and a low bicarbonate level (HCO3- = 10 mEq/L), indicating metabolic acidosis. The pCO2 is also reduced (25 mmHg), which suggests a respiratory compensatory mechanism aiming to increase acid excretion (by hyperventilating to blow off CO2) to counterbalance the acidosis.

 

This presentation is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a common complication of diabetes that leads to metabolic acidosis, elevated blood glucose, and electrolyte imbalances due to the production of ketoacids from the breakdown of fats. The high blood sugar level of 350 mg/dL supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Incorrect as the low HCO3- and acidic pH point to acidosis, not alkalosis.

 

Option C. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect as the low pCO2 is a compensatory response to the metabolic acidosis, not the primary disorder.

 

Option D. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect as this would involve an elevated pCO2, opposite of what is observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the presence of high blood sugar and the reported ABG values, metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis, should be considered.
