This condition requires prompt recognition and management, typically involving fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, and electrolyte management to reverse the ketosis and acidosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following is a suicide inhibitor?  (INICET May 2024)

 

  1. Nor-ethindrone
  2. Ritonavir
  3. Spironolactone
  4. Benzbromarone
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

A suicide inhibitor (also known as a mechanism-based inhibitor) is a type of enzyme inhibitor that binds to an enzyme and undergoes a catalytic reaction, leading to the formation of an irreversible complex. During this reaction, the inhibitor is converted into a reactive form by the enzyme itself, which then covalently binds to the enzyme, permanently inactivating it. In essence, the enzyme “commits suicide” by converting the inhibitor into a form that irreversibly binds to it, thereby blocking the enzyme's activity permanently.

 

Among the given options, nor-ethindrone, ritonavir and spironolactone are suicide inhibitors whereas benzbromarone is not. 

 

  1. Nor-ethindrone: Nor-ethindrone is a synthetic progestin that is commonly used in hormonal contraceptives. It is also classified as a suicide inhibitor due to its irreversible binding to its target enzyme, leading to permanent inhibition of enzyme activity.
  2. Ritonavir: Ritonavir is an HIV protease inhibitor that acts as a suicide inhibitor. It binds irreversibly to the HIV protease enzyme, permanently inactivating it.
  3. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is also categorized as a suicide inhibitor because it irreversibly inhibits the 17α-hydroxylase enzyme involved in steroid synthesis.
  4. Benzbromarone: Benzbromarone is a uricosuric drug used to treat gout by increasing the renal excretion of uric acid. However, it is not classified as a suicide inhibitor. While it has therapeutic uses, it does not act by irreversibly inactivating enzymes like suicide inhibitors do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suicide inhibitors, also known as mechanism-based inhibitors, irreversibly bind to and permanently inactivate their target enzymes. This type of inhibition is significant because the enzyme activity cannot be restored unless new enzymes are synthesized by the body.

 

Mnemonic to Remember Important Suicide Inhibitors:

 

“Every Nurse Sees The Clot Results Promptly”

 

  • E: Ethinyl estradiol
  • N: Norethindrone
  • S: Spironolactone
  • T: Ticlopidine
  • C: Clopidogrel
  • R: Ritonavir
  • P: Propylthiouracil

questions.text: A 4-day old baby is active and feeding well. He has a bilirubin level of 8 mg/dl. What is the next step in the management of the baby? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue breastfeeding.

 

On the fourth day, this child's bilirubin level is only 8 mg/dl, indicating physiologic jaundice. Because the child is active and feeding well, the mother should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding on a regular and exclusive basis.

 

Physiological jaundice/Icterus neonatorum is caused by increased bilirubin production from foetal red blood cell breakdown combined with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation by the immature neonatal liver.

 

It usually appears on the second or third day after birth, peaks on the fourth day at 5-6 mg/dL, and then drops to 2 mg/dL between the fifth and seventh days.

 

Note: Features suggestive of pathological jaundice:

 

  1. Jaundice appears within the first 24 hours after birth.
  2. Jaundice present at or beyond age 3 weeks or sick infant.
  3. Elevated direct (or conjugated) bilirubin level.
  4. Total Serum Bilirubin (TSB) levels above the expected normal range -Jaundice is seen in the mid-abdomen (= 15 mg/dL) and soles (- 20 mg/dL).
  5. Total Serum Bilirubin concentration not responding to phototherapy.
  6. Total Serum Bilirubin rising rapidly (i.e., crossing percentiles) in an infant receiving phototherapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exchange transfusion: exchange transfusion is not the correct option.

 

Indications of exchange transfusion are:

 

  1. History of Direct coombs test positive
  2. Cord hemoglobin < 5gm/cl and cord bilirubin >10 mg /dl
  3. History of sibling death / erythroblastosis fetalis

 

Option B. Stop breastfeeding and start phototherapy: We don’t stop breast feeding unless the baby is a case of galactosemia or lactose intolerance because in these conditions breast feeding is contraindicated.

 

Option C. IV fluids and phototherapy: IV fluids is not the right option as the baby is feeding well. We don’t give IV fluids to a baby who is feeding well.

 

Educational Objective:


In cases of physiological jaundice with mild to moderate bilirubin levels and a well-feeding, active infant, the appropriate management is to continue breastfeeding without additional interventions.

questions.text: What are the tactile hallucinations observed in instances of prolonged cocaine intoxication? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formication

 

Formication, characterized by the feeling of insects moving beneath the skin, is a notable occurrence in cases of cocaine abuse. This phenomenon is also commonly denoted as Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs.

 

COCAINE

 

  • Derived from the plant, Erythroxylum coca
  • Sigmund Freud studied its pharmacological effects and probably had an addiction to cocaine too.
  • Was initially used as a local anaesthetic (as it blocks fast sodium channels), especially for ENT surgeries.
  • Blocks dopamine and norepinephrine receptors (dopamine & NE reuptake is inhibited) resulting in-
    • Vasoconstriction: HTN, MI
    • Nasal septal perforation (nasal inhalation of cocaine results in nasal congestion and long-term use can cause nasal septal perforation)
    • Seizures
    • Jet black pigmentation of tongue
  • Routes of administration - Snorting (inhalation of finely powdered form into the nose), freebasing (smoking), I.V. and subcutaneous.

 

Intoxication

 

  • Euphoria
  • Sympathetic symptoms (tachycardia, palpitations, hypertension, sweating, mydriasis)
  • Paranoid ideations (persecutory ideations) + auditory hallucinations
  • Tactile hallucinations or cocaine bugs or magnan phenomenon or formication (sensation of insects crawling under the skin)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oneroid state is a dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness

 

Option C. Dipsomania is a historical term describing a medical condition involving an uncontrollable craving for alcohol or drugs.

 

Option D. Carphologia is a lint-picking behavior that is often a symptom of a delirious state.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding the instrument shown below? (INICET MAY 2018)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women not on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿It is used in women on thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  3. ﻿﻿﻿It is removed once the patient starts ambulating.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A, B and C

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows a pneumatic compression hose. It is used in women who are not on any thromboprophylaxis and planned for caesarean section.
  • It is also used along with pharmacotherapy in women at risk of thromboembolism undergoing a cesarean section
  • It is discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.
  • It is used because pregnancy and surgery increase the risk of thromboembolism.

 

Different guidelines are there for different societies (Both ACOG and SMFM) recommend pneumatic compression devices for all patients undergoing cesarean section. This table is from Williams and shows the different guidelines:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumatic compression devices are used for thromboembolism prevention in women undergoing cesarean sections, whether or not they are on thromboprophylaxis, and are discontinued once the patient starts ambulating post-surgery.

 

Ref: Page 2575, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Which of the following are the classical markers of a seminoma: (INICET NOV 2023)

 

  1. KIT    
  2. OCT 3
  3. PLAP
  4. HCG
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

The classical markers of a seminoma include KIT (CD117), OCT 3 (also known as OCT3/4), and PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase). These markers are commonly used in the diagnosis and characterization of seminomas due to their high specificity.

 

1. KIT (CD117): A receptor tyrosine kinase that is strongly expressed in seminomas, aiding in differentiation from other testicular neoplasms.

 

2. OCT 3 (OCT3/4): A transcription factor essential for maintaining the pluripotency of germ cells and expressed in seminomas, reflecting their embryonal origin.

 

3. PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase): Frequently elevated in seminomas, this enzyme helps in confirming the germ cell origin of the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

4. HCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): Although some seminomas may express low levels of HCG, it is not considered a classical marker like the others, being more indicative of non-seminomatous germ cell tumors.

 

HCG may be present in ~15–20% of seminomas. However it is a classical marker for Choriocarcinoma (produced by syncytiotrophoblastic cells)

 

Therefore, some seminomas can elevate serum hCG

 

However:

 

  • Not seen in all seminoma
  • More characteristic of choriocarcinoma and mixed germ cell tumors

 

Educational objective:

 

When diagnosing seminoma, clinicians should primarily focus on markers KIT, OCT3/4, and PLAP due to their high specificity and relevance to the germ cell lineage. HCG, although sometimes present, is not a classical marker for seminoma.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about skeletal muscle contraction? (INICET May 2020)

 

  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule have no role in EC coupling
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 only

 

During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

 

Excitation contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fibre (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

 

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

 

 

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane generating local end-plate potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fibre, and an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, via activating voltage gated Ca2+ channels, leading to the spread of depolarization.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fibre releases of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • Cross-linkages formed between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

 

Steps in relaxation:

 

 

Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction specially in smooth and cardiac muscle, when there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3, 4: Incorrect. Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria do not play a direct role in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 4: Incorrect. Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important for skeletal muscle contraction, and Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Option D. 1, 3, 4: Incorrect. Although Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (statement 3 is correct), Extracellular Ca2+ is not directly important and voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on T tubule needs to be activated in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During skeletal muscle contraction, Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is essential for muscle contraction.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cyclophosphamide

 

Explanation:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent used to treat various cancers and autoimmune diseases. One of its known side effects is the increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. This is due to the metabolite acrolein, which can cause urothelial damage leading to malignancy. Long-term use or high doses of cyclophosphamide significantly elevate this risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug effective against various cancers, including testicular, ovarian, and bladder cancer. However, it is not specifically associated with the development of bladder carcinoma as a side effect.

 

Option C. Taxane (e.g., paclitaxel, docetaxel): Taxanes are chemotherapeutic agents used in treating breast, ovarian, and lung cancers. They are not linked to bladder carcinoma development.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is primarily used to treat breast cancer. While it can increase the risk of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen-like effects on uterine tissue, it is not associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer.

 

Additional Information on Drugs Associated with Bladder Cancer: Several drugs have been associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, including:

  • Pioglitazone: A drug used to treat type 2 diabetes.
  • Aristolochic acid: Found in some herbal remedies.
  • Phenacetin: An analgesic and antipyretic.
  • Aminosalicylates: Used in the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapeutic agent known to be associated with the development of bladder carcinoma due to its metabolite acrolein, which can damage the bladder lining.

questions.text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or turning his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
  • BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals (otoconia) usually dislodged from the utricle. These otoconia will enter the semicircular canal and will cause change in the density of the endolymphatic fluid as well as they will inadvertently touch the cupula and cause unnecessary stimulation of the hair cells in cristae.
  • Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the utricle from the semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meniere's disease: Presents with recurrent spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting for hours associated by aural fullness, tinnitus and hearing loss.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Presents with severe, sudden-onset, spontaneous vertigo which is continuous and associated with hearing loss, nausea and vomiting.

 

Option D. Syncope is defined as a transient, self-limited loss of consciousness with an inability to maintain postural tone that is followed by spontaneous recovery.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An anti-arrhythmic drug, which is effective in both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias, is shown to have the following effect on action potential. Which of the following is the most likely drug? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Quinidine

 

  • Quinidine and procainamide are class IA anti-arrhythmic agents. These blocks Na+ channel along with potassium channel as well. This increases action potential duration (APD), which leads to QT prolongation.

     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tocainide: Tocainide is a Class IB anti-arrhythmic drug. These drugs block Na+ channels and open K+ channels, reducing the slope of phase 4 of the action potential. This effect shortens the action potential duration.

 

 

Option B. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-receptor blocker and a Class II anti-arrhythmic. It works primarily by inhibiting sympathetic input to the heart, reducing heart rate, and decreasing the force of contraction. It does not directly affect the action potential duration in the same way as Class I drugs.

 

Option D. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (Lidocaine) is a Class IB anti-arrhythmic drug. It shortens the action potential duration by blocking Na+ channels and opening K+ channels. This effect is the opposite of what is shown in the graph.

 

Note –

 

Class 1c agents like Flecainide and Encainide block sodium channels with no action on potassium channel. The image below illustrates the action potential changes when a class 1c anti-arrhythmic is used.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Class IA anti-arrhythmic agents like Quinidine prolong the action potential duration by blocking sodium and potassium channels, making them effective in treating both atrial and ventricular arrhythmias. This effect is clearly reflected in the graph provided, distinguishing it from other classes of anti-arrhythmic drugs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice. Imaging studies reveal a mass arising from the antrum of the stomach extending into the head of the pancreas with metastasis to the right lobe of the liver. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy

 

  • The clinical scenario involves carcinoma stomach infiltrating into the pancreas with liver metastasis.
  • Palliative gastrojejunostomy followed by chemotherapy is the management of choice for such cases.
  • It is a type of palliative surgery that relieves the symptoms of gastric outlet obstruction caused by tumors in the distal stomach or duodenum.
  • The procedure allows food to bypass the obstruction and enter the small intestine, improving the patient's ability to eat and preventing malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Radical gastrectomy: Radical gastrectomy involves the surgical removal of the stomach with the aim of curing the disease. This option is typically considered for localized gastric cancer that has not metastasized extensively.

 

Option C. Whipple's procedure (Pancreaticoduodenectomy): The Whipple's procedure is a complex surgical operation that involves the removal of the head of the pancreas, the duodenum, a portion of the bile duct, and sometimes part of the stomach. It is typically performed for cancers located in the head of the pancreas, not stomach cancer.

 

Option D. Gastrectomy with right hepatectomy: This surgical approach involves the removal of the stomach (gastrectomy) and the right lobe of the liver. It might be considered if the tumor is locally advanced and involves both the stomach and liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For patients with advanced gastric cancer extending into adjacent organs and with liver metastasis, the appropriate management often involves palliative measures, such as gastrojejunostomy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life, followed by chemotherapy.
  • Curative surgical options are generally not feasible in the presence of metastasis.

questions.text:
The drowned dead body of a young man found in the sea and was brought in for postmortem examination. Which of the following findings do you see in seawater drowning? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. Hypernatremia
  2. Hyponatremia
  3. Hyperkalemia
  4. Myocardial anoxia
  5. Hemodilution
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1 and 4   

 

 

Seawater Drowning Characteristics:

1. Hypernatremia: Seawater is hypertonic compared to the body fluids, leading to an increase in sodium levels in the blood.

4. Myocardial anoxia: Lack of oxygen due to drowning can lead to myocardial anoxia.

 

Fresh water drowning Vs Salt water Drowning

 

 

Other Options

 

2. Hyponatremia: Seen in freshwater drowning.

 

3. Hyperkalemia: Seen in freshwater drowning due to hemolysis.

 

5. Hemodilution: Seen in freshwater drowning due to absorption of water.

 

Educational Objective

 

DIFFERENCES BETWEEN FRESH WATER AND SALT WATER DROWNING

questions.text: An intraocular lens was placed uneventfully in a young patient during cataract surgery. What should be done thereafter? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Never replaced

 

In the case of a successful and uneventful intraocular lens (IOL) implantation during cataract surgery, there is typically no need to replace the IOL. These lenses are designed to be permanent solutions that do not require routine replacement. Modern IOLs are made from durable materials that are meant to last a lifetime without degrading or causing adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IOL replaced every 10 years: There is no routine schedule for replacing IOLs as they are designed to last a lifetime.

 

Option C. Replaced when secondary cataract develops: Secondary cataract (or posterior capsule opacification) can often be treated with a simple laser procedure called a posterior capsulotomy, not by replacing the IOL.

 

Option D. Replaced when presbyopia develops: Presbyopia is related to the lens of the eye and loss of its elasticity, affecting near vision; IOLs implanted during cataract surgery do not correct presbyopia inherent to aging, but specific types of IOLs can be chosen to address presbyopia at the time of surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An IOL replacement (IOL exchange) may be done under the following conditions:

 

  • Incorrect IOL placed-Incorrect power or Incorrect Type
  • Posterior or anterior dislocation of IOL
  • Hyphema
  • Asymmetrical Haptic Placement
  • Sunset Syndrome
  • Lens-Bag Decentration

questions.text: During resuscitation in a patient with severe hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Local anesthesia toxicity

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used as a treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). If a patient accidentally receives an excessive dose of local anesthetic, or if the local anesthetic is inadvertently injected into a blood vessel, it can lead to systemic toxicity, manifesting as CNS symptoms (like seizures) and cardiovascular collapse. Intralipid acts as a lipid sink, effectively reducing the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma and thereby reversing the toxic effects. This is why this option is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asphyxia due to drowning: While drowning can certainly lead to hypotension and arrhythmias, it does so because of hypoxia and other related complications. Intralipid injection is not a recognized treatment for drowning and its consequences.

 

Option C. Electrocution: While electrocution can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other cardiac problems, the primary treatment is to address the rhythm disturbances directly, treat burns, and support the patient. Intralipid would not be used in this context.

 

Option D. Pulseless electrical activity (PEA): PEA refers to a condition where there is organized or semi-organized electrical activity in the heart (seen on EKG) but no palpable pulse. The treatment for PEA is high-quality CPR, following the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm, and addressing any potential reversible causes. Intralipid is not a standard treatment for PEA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically for treating local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) by acting as a lipid sink to reduce the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 885

choices.text: Follow up with beta-hCG
Suction and evacuation

questions.text: A patient with 12 weeks amenorrhea presents with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the cervical os is open and the uterus is 14 weeks size. USG shows a snowstorm appearance. The next best step in the management is? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Suction and evacuation

 

Explanation:

 

The snowstorm appearance on ultrasound is characteristic of a complete molar pregnancy (hydatidiform mole). Molar pregnancies are abnormal pregnancies where there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Complete Molar Pregnancy: Presents with vaginal bleeding, an enlarged uterus greater than expected for gestational age, and a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound.
  • Treatment: The primary treatment for a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue.
  • Post-Evacuation Surveillance: After evacuation, it is crucial to monitor beta-hCG levels to ensure complete removal of the molar tissue and to detect any possible malignancy (e.g., choriocarcinoma).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Medical management: Medical management is not appropriate for molar pregnancy, as surgical evacuation is necessary.

 

Option B. Follow up with beta-hCG: Beta-hCG monitoring is essential after the initial treatment but not before the evacuation of the molar tissue.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is not the first line of treatment for a molar pregnancy unless there are specific complications or risk factors warranting such an invasive procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of a molar pregnancy involves suction and evacuation to remove the abnormal trophoblastic tissue, followed by post-evacuation surveillance with beta-hCG levels to monitor for persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.

 

Ref: William’s Textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 614

questions.text: A 5-Month-old neonate is brought to the emergency department with increased irritability, poor feeding, and two episodes of seizures. On examination, the infant appears lethargic with a bulging fontanelle. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows elevated white blood cells, high protein, and low glucose, consistent with bacterial meningitis. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Streptococcus agalactiae

 

Explanation:

 

Neonatal meningitis is a serious infection commonly caused by specific pathogens due to the neonate’s immature immune system. The most likely causative organism in this clinical scenario is Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus), which is the leading cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis, particularly in the first few weeks of life. This organism is commonly transmitted from the maternal genital tract during delivery.

 

Early vs. Late Onset Meningitis:

 

Early-onset meningitis usually occurs within the first 72 hours of life and is most often caused by Group B streptococcus.

 

Late-onset meningitis affects premature infants more commonly and is typically caused by organisms such as coagulase-negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, and Klebsiella.

 

Common Causes:

 

Group B streptococci are the most frequent cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis.

Escherichia coli is the most common cause of early-onset sepsis and meningitis among very low birth weight infants (less than 1500 g).

 

Evaluation and Diagnosis:

 

Neonates are particularly susceptible to infections due to their immature cellular and humoral immunity. Any infant aged 28 days or younger presenting with fever or signs of sepsis should undergo a comprehensive evaluation, including CBC, differential count, blood cultures, urine culture, chest radiograph, and lumbar puncture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Escherichia coli: Commonly causes neonatal meningitis, especially in very low birth weight infants, but Group B streptococcus remains the most frequent in full-term neonates.

 

Option C) Staphylococcus aureus: Typically associated with late-onset infections, particularly in hospitalized infants, but less likely in early-onset neonatal meningitis.

 

Option D) Klebsiella species: Another pathogen that can cause neonatal infections, especially in late-onset cases, but less common than Group B streptococcus in the early neonatal period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B streptococcus) is the primary cause of neonatal meningitis and sepsis due to the neonate’s immature immune system. Early identification and appropriate management are crucial to prevent severe complications and improve outcomes in affected infants.

choices.text: Wavy fibers
Neutrophils in cardiac muscle
Swelling of cells
Eosinophilic contraction band

questions.text: Histology of reperfused myocardium is suggestive of which of the following features? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Eosinophilic contraction band 

 

Light microscopy of reperfused myocardium reveals eosinophilic contraction bands. When blood supply is restored 12-24 hours after MI, they occur in irreversibly injured myocytes with damaged membranes.

 

 

Because the vasculature is injured during the period of ischemia and leaks when flow is restored hence a re-perfused infarct is usually hemorrhagic.

 

Microscopic examination reveals that myocytes that were irreversibly injured during reperfusion frequently have contraction bands, which are intensely eosinophilic intracellular "stripes" composed of closely packed sarcomeres. These are caused by myofibril contractions that are exaggerated when perfusion is restored, exposing the interior of dead cells with damaged plasma membranes to a high concentration of calcium ions from the plasma. Reperfusion thus not only saves reversibly injured cells but also changes the morphology of lethally injured cells.

 

Because of impaired calcium cycling and sarcolemma damage, intracellular calcium levels rise during ischemia. After reperfusion, this causes augmented and uncontrolled contraction of myofibrils.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wavy fibers:

 

  • Description: Wavy fibers are an early histologic change seen in myocardial infarction, indicating stretching of non-contracting fibers.
  • Timing: These are seen in the early stages of ischemic injury before reperfusion.

 

Option B. Neutrophils in cardiac muscle:

 

  • Description: Neutrophil infiltration is a typical feature of the inflammatory response that occurs a few hours to days after myocardial infarction.
  • Timing: These are seen in the subsequent inflammatory phase following ischemic injury and are not specific to reperfusion injury.

 

Option C. Swelling of cells:

 

  • Description: Cellular swelling is a sign of reversible injury and occurs early in the ischemic process due to the failure of ion pumps.
  • Timing: This occurs before the irreversible injury and reperfusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Eosinophilic contraction bands are a characteristic histological feature of reperfused myocardium, indicating irreversible injury and exaggerated myofibril contraction due to high intracellular calcium levels upon restoration of blood flow.

questions.text: During fetal autopsy, what is the order of examination to differentiate between live and stillbirth? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Head > Abdomen > Thorax

 

During a fetal autopsy, the abdomen is typically examined before the thorax to assess the level of the diaphragm. The position of the diaphragm can indicate whether respiration has taken place. If the diaphragm is at the level of the 4th to 5th rib, it suggests that respiration has not occurred. If it is at the level of the 6th to 7th rib, it indicates that respiration has taken place. Although there is no strict rule about the order of examining the head, it is generally preferred to examine the head first to check for any hemorrhages. The correct sequence provided in the options is Head > Abdomen > Thorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thorax > Abdomen > Thorax: Incorrect. This option repeats the thorax examination and does not include the head, which is important for checking for hemorrhages.

 

Option B. Thorax > Head > Abdomen: Incorrect. The abdomen should be examined before the thorax to check the diaphragm level, which is crucial for determining whether respiration has occurred.

 

Option D. Head > Thorax > Abdomen: Incorrect. This option does not follow the necessary sequence where the abdomen should be examined before the thorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a fetal autopsy, the correct sequence of examination is Head > Abdomen > Thorax, with the abdomen being opened before the thorax to check the diaphragm level for respiration evidence
